abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts, achieved through a highly
            satisfactory Bank performance, and a satisfactory borrower
            performance. Technical assistance (TA) supporting
            politically difficult, transition reforms have a higher
            chance of success if designed as an integral part of the
            Bank's broader sector assistance strategy, and at the
            policy level if supporting relevant conditions in adjustment
            operation(s). However, the reverse is also true - as
            observed in the Implementation Completion Reports on both
            Private and Financial Sector Adjustment Credits (PFSAC)
            (I/II), the Bank's ability to provide extensive
            technical assistance on a timely basis, has been enormously
            important in enabling the PFSAC program achieve its
            objectives on enterprise sector reform, and further recorded
            in relevant policy conditions on privatization of
            State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), and measures to improve the
            business environment. Therefore, implementation of a complex
            and politically sensitive TA program does not only require a
            fully functioning implementing agency, but also constant
            support at the level of senior policy-making. In this case,
            from the very inception the Project enjoyed full support of
            the reform-minded Ministry of Economy and Privatization
            (MOEP), who protected the implementing agencies from
            political risks. Further lessons reinforce the importance of
            donor coordination, and of creating efficient project
            administration arrangements.
